author: elayne_malachite
content: It will not impact average gas prices.

author: ankur2534
content: absolutely it will

author: ankur2534
content: Even right now, plenty of people are paying 150 gwei when a safe, fast gasprice is 100 gwei. Thats due to problems in fee estimation that will be improved under 1559

author: sky.cactus
content: It won't decrease supply, or demand.  It will improve efficiency which may have *some* impact.  Don't expect any significant changes though.

author: definitelynotcharles7176
content:
Ok. 

The most shocking thing from the video is Micah's unreasonably high ability to communicate complex concepts.

author: maxvoltage.
content: <@301186049323958275> not sure if this is the right channel, but while we understood what you said, it was hard to exactly relate that to the real world.

author: maxvoltage.
content: One question I have... you gave 2 examples of MEV.  The 2nd examply you gave on the stream, is that already included in the general tx fee reward?  So, the pool can't hide it?

author: maxvoltage.
content: And <@!301186049323958275> thanks for your time tonight.  Really apprecated it.  see question above.

author: sky.cactus
content: MEV tends to include the full arbitrage amount.  A portion of that goes to miners in the form of transaction fees, and that is already accounted for in fees in the block.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, a block producer (pool) could receive backchannel payment instead which is a bit harder to notice.

author: maxvoltage.
content: <@!301186049323958275> yes, I understood the first example with the back channel payments but was the 2nd example the same or more out in the open?

author: maxvoltage.
content: The problem miners are having is that it seems like the topic of MEV is a distraction to 1559 and don't understand why they are in the same discussion.

author: maxvoltage.
content: I understand that <@!528251935829262351> is stating that MEV is part of the total rewards so it should be included, but this isn't about total rewards but rewards available to individual miners.

author: sky.cactus
content: The reason MEV is related to 1559 is talked about later in the call.  It has to do with how much 1559 will hurt your mining rewards.  Any gas price auctions will still go predominately to the miners, even if you do nothing today.

author: sky.cactus
content: There are estimates out there, and I think <@318272156305981440> plans to run some numbers over the coming days to try to get a better idea of how much of the fee revenue is auction revenue which is largely unaffected by 1559.

author: sky.cactus
content: Going over MEV at the start was basically setting the stage for that, and also helping to educate miners on how they can make money off of it, unrelated to 1559.

author: maxvoltage.
content: <@!301186049323958275> Thanks.  Just to confirm... MEV continues after 1559 is introduced, correct?  Quite a few miners left the call thinking MEV was replaced with the tip in 1559.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yep.  MEV is almost entirely unaffected by 1559.

author: gpuhoarder
content:
Which begs the question - if MEV is expected to continue in a high volume way enough to be significant for all miners, doesn‚Äôt that mean 1559 only serves to regulate UX / consistency in the base portion of MEV? If MEV is truly large, miner tip must be perpetually large and will fill in any gap in unburnt gas, since non-defi-arbitrage transactions will have to include a miner tip in the same magnitude as those/MEV today to ensure block inclusion. Which means all participants in ETH transactions that value inclusion will need proportional miner tip. So miner tip becomes  the new gas and the burnt gas / 1559 becomes increasingly inconsequential 

This really means 1559 has no significant effect

author: gpuhoarder
content: Either MEV is large enough to make up for burnt gas, or it is infrequent enough to not impact 1559 dynamic in terms of congestion/competition. Pick a poison.

author: sky.cactus
content: MEV extractors generally don't fill entire blocks.  They just have a small number of very high value transactions per block.

author: gpuhoarder
content: Which would mean that in agregate, they represent a proportionally low average value and would not ‚Äúmake up‚Äù for burnt gas in any significant way.

author: sky.cactus
content: When I say high value, I mean they can entirely dwarf all other transaction fees in a block with one or two MEV transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: When most transactions have a gas price of 100, they may have a gas price of 10,000.

author: sky.cactus
content: They are playing a completely different game.

author: gpuhoarder
content: Understood. However I haven‚Äôt seen evidence that only 1 opportunity per 13-15 second for such arbitrage exists as a forward concern. It would be rational to expect either a growing or diminishing number of such opportunities exist.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think <@528251935829262351> has a chart that shows historic MEV vs normal transaction fee volume.

author: gpuhoarder
content: In the former case that results in a situation where ultimately the block is full of such opportunities, and transaction cost becomes commiserate with miner tip. In the later, it can not be expected that MEV would reasonably replace gas revenue for miners

author: gpuhoarder
content: I am not arguing the importance of MEV, but that positioning MEV as a replacement for transaction fees available to miners is disingenuous

author: sky.cactus
content: The *entire* blockchain can't be full of purely arbitrage opportunities because there wouldn't be any room left for people to do actual transactions that then get arbitraged.  üòÑ

author: sky.cactus
content: One can imagine a future though where half a block is MEV extraction, and the other half of the block is "regular users".

author: sky.cactus
content: To be clear, I'm not suggesting that MEV is a replacement for miners.  I merely am trying to help miners be aware of the opportunity they have.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oops, we should move this to <#798586271445680129> (just realized which channel we are in).

author: gpuhoarder
content: I support that education, it is important if only to prevent pools from extracting that miner value without equitable distribution

author: definitelynotcharles7176
content:
We might expect that MEV to fall over time, as awareness will "arbitrage it out" (?). I think perhaps this was part of <@!301186049323958275>'s underlying goal. 

Some things Micah said don't quite check out:
> Yep.  MEV is almost entirely unaffected by 1559.
> The reason MEV is related to 1559 is talked about later in the call.  It has to do with how much 1559 will hurt your mining rewards.  Any gas price auctions will still go predominately to the miners, even if you do nothing today.

Well, actually, no.


1. The essence of why MEV is a thing is because miners right now have free rein over the blocks they get their hands on. I think 1559's key objectives (like, an explicit, prominent point in the EIP-1559) was to make classes of "off chain" transactions much more costly, so we expect some MEV transactions to be curtailed. (You have to pay the base fee to do any funky stuff, whereas before you paid nothing, and now there's a cost).

2. Also, the "inclusion fee" (tip) gas prices is supposed to be vastly lower (1 gwei?) and this might also indirectly lower MEV, maybe even linearly to the reduced inclusion fee, but I haven't thought about this.

3. Also, generally making more space available for spiky transactions (because now you have 2x blocks) seems like it exactly gives bandwidth for the "funders" of high transactions that dish out the real paydirt in MEV. Maybe this will cause them to be able to skip making this phat phat payments, but I haven't thought about this.

But hey, I dunno really, I read the EIP and the top three paragraphs of some MEV article.

I agree that MEV is not directly relevant to the 1559 discussion. It does objectively help many miners here.

Relevant to the deeper discussion on 1559, I think pointing out the existence of MEV is useful in showing that there's a lot of money on the table that miners are not picking up, and this is a comment on some of the other ideas Micah brought up and the current state of miner organization as a whole.
